Original Bills: An Act establishing a sick leave bank for Christopher Trigilio, an employee of the trial court
Summarized Bills: Summary: An Act establishing a sick leave bank for Christopher Trigilio, an employee of the trial court. This bill mandates the trial court of the commonwealth to create a sick leave bank for Christopher Trigilio, an employee of the court. Other employees of the trial court are allowed to voluntarily donate their sick, personal, or vacation days to this bank for Trigilio's use. If Trigilio ends his employment or requests to dissolve the sick leave bank, any remaining time will be transferred to the trial court paid leave bank. The sick leave bank days can only be used for absences related to the illness or disability that led to the creation of the bank, as determined by the trial court.

Original Bills: An Act providing living organ donor protections
Summarized Bills: Summary: An Act providing living organ donor protections. This bill aims to protect the rights of living organ donors in the insurance sector. It mandates that insurance companies cannot decline, limit, or discriminate in coverage based on a person's status as a living organ donor. The bill also prohibits insurance providers from preventing a person from donating an organ as a condition of maintaining their coverage. The legislation further requires the commissioner of insurance to enforce these rules and the department to make materials related to live organ donation available to the public. Violations of these provisions are considered unfair competition or deceptive practices.

Original Bills: An Act authorizing the State Board of Retirement to grant creditable service to Paul Lemelin
Summarized Bills: Summary: An Act authorizing the State Board of Retirement to grant creditable service to Paul Lemelin. This bill allows the state board of retirement to credit Paul Lemelin, an employee of the Franklin Regional Council of Governments, with service time for the period from November 14, 2011 to January 20, 2023. This credited service time will be used to calculate his superannuation retirement allowance. However, before any retirement allowance becomes effective, Paul Lemelin must pay an amount equivalent to what would have been withheld if he had received regular compensation during this period, plus buyback interest. The payment can be made in a lump sum or in installments, as determined by the state board of retirement. The act will take effect immediately upon its passage.

Original Bills: An Act providing living organ donor protections
Summarized Bills: Summary: An Act providing living organ donor protections. This bill aims to protect the rights of living organ donors in the insurance sector. It mandates that the commissioner of insurance establish rules to enforce sections of various chapters related to insurance. The bill also requires the department to make available to the public any materials related to live organ donation from reputable organizations. It prohibits insurance providers from declining or limiting coverage, or otherwise discriminating against a person solely based on their status as a living organ donor. This applies to policies against disability from injury or disease, life insurance, group or individual annuity, pure endowment contract, and long-term care insurance. Any violation of these provisions is considered an unfair method of competition or an unfair or deceptive act or practice.

Original Bills: An Act providing coverage for hearing aids
Summarized Bills: Summary: An Act providing coverage for hearing aids. This bill mandates that all active or retired employees of the commonwealth or their dependents who are insured under the group insurance commission, as well as those covered under certain accident and sickness insurance policies, hospital service plans, medical service agreements, and health maintenance contracts, are entitled to coverage for the cost of one hearing aid per hearing-impaired ear every 36 months. The coverage includes up to $500 and 80% coverage of the next $1,500 for each hearing aid, upon a written statement from the treating physician that the hearing aids are necessary. The coverage also includes all related services prescribed by a licensed audiologist or hearing instrument specialist, such as the initial hearing aid evaluation, fitting and adjustments, and supplies, including ear molds. Insured individuals can choose a higher priced hearing aid and pay the difference in cost above the limit without any financial or contractual penalty. The benefits are not subject to any greater deductible, coinsurance, copayments or out-of-pocket limits than other benefits provided by the insurer. The bill also allows for insurers to offer greater coverage for hearing aids than required by this act. The act applies to all relevant policies, contracts and certificates of health insurance delivered, issued or renewed on or after January 1, 2014.
